This is my first review here on this website so please inform me if I broke any rules or conventions while writing this review. Now I noticed that all the people here who have left a review on "Kampfer" have all mist out on, what I believe, to be a vitally important aspect of the show as a whole. After watching kampfer and kämpfer für die liebe I could not help but notice the communist symbolism so deeply ingrained in the heart of the series. 
Many people accuse Kampfer of having a trite and predictable plot full of fan service and unnecessary innuendo. They claimthat the characters lack personality and are there only to there to act as fodder to make up for the crappy and uninspired show as a whole. While I do not disagree with this statement I will say that the over arching themes of the show as a whole  makes the boring and uninspired characters worth putting up with. The premise of kampfer revolves around two groups of girls, one with blue brackets, and one with red battling each other in a school setting. it is explained in later episodes that they are made kampfers by a group of mysterious beings known only as "moderators" a force that oversees the conflict and creation of "kampfers". The kampfers fight each other to resolve a cosmic conflict taking place between two forces "blue and red". This is where I began the realize the communist symbolism deep within Kampfer.


 The blue and red factions represent the inherent infighting between the capitalist upper class. They represent the big multinational corporations like Exxon and Saudi Aramco vying for power in the global playing field, fighting tooth and nail for domination of their respective industries. The moderators, a sort of peace keeper in the Kampfer universe are the governments of the nations around the world. Because an extended conflict between thee corporations would essentially tear the world apart the moderators then passed the burden of the infighting to the Kampfers, random girls they selected from Earth. These Kampfers are the working class. Just like the Great Russian Revolution in 1917 the Kampfers led by Shizuku, a red Kampfer decide to band together and resist the bidding of the moderators. These Kampfers are the proletariat. They are pushed beyond their breaking point, forced to fight for a battle they dont even care about. The kampfers were pushed beyond their breaking point as their friends died around them and they are forced to rise up against their oppressors. Just like Marx envisioned in his Manifesto, the Kampfers rose up against their chains because they had already lost the lives of their sisters that came before them. They rose up against the cruel oppression of the moderators. They refused to fight against their will and rebelled against the their overlords. In a classic act of civil disobedience worthy of Gandhi himself they laid down their arms and refused to fight one another. 


Of course out friends the moderators could not allow this. In an equally classic move they created their own fighting force. The White kampfers, a sort of police force designed to tear apart the bond that had formed between the blue and red kampfers and force them once again into perpetual conflict. This is where Senou Natsaru comes in. The gender bending of Kampfer plays an important role in the communist symbolism of kamfper. Kampfers were always female. Males could not be kampfers and were not involved in the eternal conflict between red and blue. Natsaru was like an outsider. a bystander at best. When he became a Kampfer he was dragged into the battle between the people and the state, between freedom and injustice. Natsaru was in many ways like Vladimir Lenin. Lenin was born into a wealthy bourgeois family. Both were dragged into the conflict. Although Lenin became a revolutionary willingly the similarities are far to deep to ignore. Natsaru and Lenin both became the leader of their respective struggles. However there is one major difference between Natsaru and Lenin. Kampfer is still inherently an ecchi anime, it still needs to appease the carnal desires of countless adolescent males and in that regard it made Natsaru a an inexperienced leader. Immature and lacking any formal knowledge about his cause Natsaru would be forced to "grown up" and learn to lead his comrades to overthrow the opposition. 


However Natsaru would be hampered by numerous obstacles, namely his nemesis Sakura Kaede. Natsaru is not a natural born leader. As a male he seemed to be relatively shy but as a kampfer that shyness seems to have increased ten fold. Sakura acts as the temptation of materialistic wealth and total power. Natsaru must learn to overcome these challenges if he is to ever lead his allies to a final victory against the moderators. The most interesting part about kampfer however is the squabbling between the red and blue factions themselves. Here kampfer gives itself a sense of realism and the fallibility of human nature. Humans can never unite fully and completely. The struggle against the moderators although universal among all of the kampfers do not prevent human nature. The kampfers often fight among themselves. The struggle to win Natsaru's heart between Shizuku, Akane, and Mikoto are just like the struggle to win Stalin's approval between Field Marshal Zhukov and NKVD head Lavrentiy Beria. The internal struggle between the Kampfers themselves perfectly mirror the constant vying for power in communist politics themselves. 


I have not watched enough anime to give a accurate judge on the sound and art style of the show itself but I have read enough books to realize that the story behind kampfer far surpasses the plot of any anime I have watched so far. Kampfer is a story of the struggle between the people and the state, of the fight between freedom and oppression, of the fragile nature of the human mind, of the oppressed majority and the privileged minority, and the perpetual fight between communism and capitalist oppression.

I think this anime is very unique in the way it plots out the story an how they present the characters. I think they could have dug deeper into the story a bit more. I really enjoyed this anime because of the comedic moments with the tad bits of romance here and there, the main protagonist is very airheaded and I think his personality is what makes the series interesting to watch as well as it makes you want to see certain things happen or certain people to get to together. The story line is very unique as I said before but the way theyintroduce the characters and how you see their relationships progress through the anime is interesting to watch. I think this anime is the sort of one that you watch if you have free time and don't know what to watch.

I did say that I wanted to watch a magical girl-esque kind of anime, but this was not what I expected. 
Kampfer, the anime that I can't really describe. Well, this is awkward, so I guess I'll get into the review now.
Story: Well, story-wise, I think that Harakiri Tiger pretty much explained the entire premise of the show with his short explanation. There's a bunch of girls having to fight a war that doesn't really involve them. Simple, right? Well, it was, but then Natsuru got tied up in this war. But more about that in character. Kampfer's plot is kind of there, a bitmore than Guilty Crown, somehow. But overall, the plot is simple: finish the war that others started. It's a simple premise, but they do put in some fight scenes to help remind the viewers that this isn't just fanservice.


Art: The art in Kampfer is great, with visuals and everything being brought to life with the shadings. Natsuru's transformation scene is animated really well, even if it is really fanservice-y. And speaking of fanservice, there's a lot. Like, so much that it transcends the manga. Even the ending song has fanservice in the animation! But besides me only allowing a certain amount of fanservice, I will say that they draw the fanservice well.


Sound: The voice acting in Kampfer is well, what I expected. The personality changes between Sakura's regular personality and her true self is played really well. But the one thing that did confuse me was Natsuru. No offense to Marina Inoue (who did her part very well), but seeing as how he's a teenage male, I expected a deeper voice. But besides the voice acting, I thought that the opening and endings were pretty good. The ending worked well, with Natsuru and Sakura having a duet, almost like they were having a conversation.


Character: The characters are really contrasted well, with Natsuru's density, Shizuku's sadism, and Akane's split personality being easy to detect. But outside of personality, the characters didn't really develop at all. Natsuru still stayed his dense and sometimes derpy self, and the 3 girls kept getting thirsty for him. 


Enjoyment: Even though I listed lots of bad points about Kampfer, that really was what had me interested and kept me watching. Even if episode 13 was basically borderline hentai, this anime was still pretty enjoyable, and I'd rewatch it just for kicks. I guess that's why I randomly rated it 10/10. 


I'm not changing my score.

So, here you have Fighter. An anime with many elements of its genre, not exactly new in any way shape or form. I do not tend to watch anime of this kind, however for the most part I found it quite enjoyable. There was a lot to like, and a lot to dislike about this anime but, as there are so many reviews that go super in depth, I will just share my own personal feelings on this anime.
Story: 7 - Classic fighting style anime, you have a few battles here in there, No real explenation whythroughout the majority of the anime. Basically its just two sides fighting eachother, However there is no reason given as to why there is fighting until the very end, nor is there a reason given as to why the fighters must be all female. Next to that, there is no depth into a lot of the plot points created. I know anime like these are just seedy to get you to want to go read the manga, but regardless of that, it still feels like it could have been made a bit better than it was. I personally plan to read the manga in the near future, However that doesn't excuse the lack of closure onto this series, nor does it excuse the god awful 12th episode, If they left it at Ep 11 for this I would have been far happier with the ending.


Art: 9 - So, I don't know why but for some reason I really like the way this anime looks, Its flashy, bright colours and catching. the character designs are animated well, the scenes are created well enough to give the atmosphere without having to even know what they are saying. Generally just enjoyable to look at. However, everyone has their own tastes, so take it as you will.


Sound: 8 - I really can't explain this. Nothing sounded off to me so im shooting in the dark here. I apologise.


Character: 9 - I will preface this by saying that I really only cared about Shizuki through most of the series, she is by far my favourite and most appealing character. This is obviously a bias as she fits pretty closely to the ideal woman I would have in mind, However, disregarding that, the characters don't really have a backstory, its not a bad thing because this anime is not deep enough for them, So moving on to the characters themselves, Shizuki is basically your standard Kuudere type, however changes a bit and doesn't seem so cold in general within 1-2 episodes. She without any clear reason falls for the MC and continues to have her feelings ignored until the end. Generally though, an interesting character, only truly interested in the MC and has no qualms showing her affections. We move on to Akane, She gets introduced very quick as a badass, foul mouthed person who wants nothing more than to fight, However after she is saved by the MC from a falling poll (which he himself makes fall) she disengages and later shows up as her normal, shy self which also, has inexplicedly fallen for the MC over time. she is quick to assume and then quick to get shut down and become embarressed. Asides from her Kampfer side she is not bold and does not get what she wants, generally speaking. Next up, Kondou, the childhoold friend of our MC, for a good portion you see nothing but postcard images from her travelling around the world, suddenly she shows up and has also become a Kampfer, weird huh, everyone around the main character is a Kampfer. anyways, Kondou is an outspoken girl who clearly has, what a suprise, affection for the MC. she dislikes his Kampfer side, however adores his normal side and shows clear jelousy of the other girls whom have gone to the MC. Second to last, we have Kaede, my absolute, most hated character. we are introduced to her as a cute, idol-like person who has slight affections to the Main character. however after the MC turns into a Kampfer, we are quickly made aware that she is, in fact a lesbian who loves the other side of the MC, as most of the other characters in this story just so happen to be lesbians (speaking to the girls side of the school) it is made largly apparent that she has 0 true interest in the MC other than to get to his hidden female form. That is litterally her only motive through and through. Lastly, we have the MC, Natsuru. We are introduced to him as a female, he has transformed thanks to the power of some beings called the "moderators" and so his life is completely messed up, he now randomly (till he learns shit) turns into a girl and is stuck with the mixed up feelings of everyone. For the most part he is an annoying little shit, but that is because despite knowing that Kaede is a complete 100% lesbian, he is still only interested in her, even in his male state. It is honestly one of the most annoying ploys I have seen thus far in anime. Moveing on, he gradually grows and becomes closer to the other three girls mentioned, closest becoming to Shizuku, as they go on a date, have their first kisses together, and end up nearly sharing a bed, if you get what I mean. it is her that reverts him back near the end with the events that happen. However as he is star crossed over Kaede, he does not immedietly realize Shizukus' or the other girls feelings for him and believes their actions to be malevolent or not entirely benign. quite simply he is your standard harem MC, however he has a bit of a complex over one girl. that just about covers him 


Enjoyment: 8 - I really enjoyed this anime, id honestly recommend it, however I will say to skip Ep 12. Lastely, I know for sure I will enjoy the Manga more. So keep that in mind.


Overall: 7 - as an overall anime. I give it a 7. It has its good points, its bad points, but in the end it is not really anything new. it has a few interesting concepts that are badly explored and an ending that makes me want to give it a 5 with high inner scores. that aside. it is still good.


(TL:DR on my ramblings. I enjoy Shizuku, Sorry I can't give a super good review but I am new to this)

Kämpfer's a strange case. 
Story first, I guess, even though that wouldn't seem to the the mentality of the creators. We follow Natsuru Senou, pretty much your average schoolguy. He wakes up one morning to find that he's now a Kämpfer - people that fight with superpowers for reasons unknown. Think Power Rangers, if they fought another team of Power Rangers. Thing is, since Kämpfers are exclusively female, when he 'suits up', he swaps gender, becoming female. Shenanigans ensue as he cannot control when he changes.
It starts off pretty strong, with a fun premise and some likeable characters put into funny scenarios. The problem lieswith the show's lack of any real focus: the entire series seems to revolve around fanservice, and particularly in the later episodes it kind of falls apart into the generic harem that we've seen so many times, and the 'grand reveal' of the series comes off in an 'Oh. That's it?' kind of way. The show had - and still did have be the end of the series - lots of potential, but so much of it is wasted as screentime is taken away from the Kämpfer battles and Natsuru struggling with leading a double life and given to every female under the sun throwing themselves at him. The ending has almost no closure - even if you sit through Für die Liebe, the two-part sequel series - and there are so many loose threads left hanging that it may as well have just cut off randomly. And topping it all off we have the most ignorant anime character since Monkey D. Luffy - except instead of being endearing, it's infuriating as he fails to notice that every girl in 100 miles is trying to make a move on him.\n\n
Overall, I give Kämpfer a 6 - it's a fun enough watch, at least for the first two thirds or so while it still has some degree of focus, but it's severely dragged back by the lack of any real plot development and the sheer missed potential here. Kämpfer, you could easily have been great, but instead, you're just another face in the crowd.

I'm usually a huge fan of gender bender anime/manga, so after reading the description I thought it would be a an action/adventure based comedy, which is sort of unusual for the genre, but this was nothing like what I expected, it turned out to be a 'fan service' based, really awful ecchi love polygon, with the action and what should have been the main story line was sat out on the side lines of the show.
Story 6/10 - The only reason why I am rating it this high, is because, as mentioned it does introduce itself as something that will be unique and interesting andit maintains it for about 2 1/2 episodes and then it becomes rubbish that's  been reused a hundred thousand times and done better with other anime. The story line is just completely derailed by the ecchi comedy/love polygon and even ignored by the characters themselves. But that's not all, the story also takes some really weird turns in itself, even away from the ecch;i at sometimes it feels like the randomness in anime like Ebiten.


Art 5/10 - Wasn't really anything special, but it wasn't poorly done either. Very plain unmemorable characters that have been seen time and time again in ecchi comedy. Atmosphere wasn't that great, but shadows and lighting accents were quite exceptional. The pallet of the atmosphere consisted of your general comedy school life anime; light blue skies, sun always shining, grass really green.


Sound 5/10 -Noting special here either, your pretty basic comedy OP/ED. The voice actors weren't that great, their reactions and lines weren't very realistic at all and they never seemed to convey emotions in a realistic manner, though that is the scripts fault more than anything else. At least the voicing wasn't whiny and shrill like what you mostly hear in these types of anime. 


Characters 2/10 -And if it wasn't dead before, here is where the anime surely dies. Instead of developing any of the characters emotions or relationships, they just throw some clueless guy who turns into a girl into a harem and kill the whole story and premise of why I thought it would be alright to watch it in the first place. The only character that seems to be aware of the main storyline is even deviated into the whole harem thing about half way through the anime.


Enjoyment 6/10 - Despite the horrible execution and disappointment this anime turned out to be for me, it did keep me laughing. It may have been crappy fan service that's been done before, but it puts the main character in those awkward/funny situations that make the gender bender genre appealing to me.


Overall 4.8/10 -Overall the producers took something that could have been cool and unique and destroyed it for 'fan service' and crap. Recommend to anybody that was going to watch the anime on that premise to stay away. However, if you like to watch anime for the ecchi comedy and harems rather than story line, than this is definitely one you should check out.

Story (5/10)
I got to say I really liked the story at the beginning. It was something new. Nothing unique but new. Especially to me. But unfortunately the story got lost after, I think the 9th episode. From then on, it was nothing more than a smooth harem hentai. It's really really sad how it turned out because the story had much potential and it could've gotten a nice ending. 
Art (6/10)
It was a time ago since I watched the anime. It's not unusual for 1court anime to be nicely animated and colorized. I can't say that much about it.
Sound (6/10)
Well most of the voices wereactually pretty annoying. Mostly of the main character.\n
I liked the battling music but the rest could've been a little better.\n\n
Character (7/10)\n
The characters are of course not that unique. There weren't many time shown how they act at home. I actually don't remember one of them that well. With that I mean they're no characters which will leave a mark in your mind.\n\n
Enjoyment (5/10) \n
It was kinda funny how the hero slipped into one awkward situation after another though it was pretty obvious what'll happen next. \n
However the fun and my interest got lost soon as I said. \n\n
Overall (5/10) \n
It's not a great waste of time but I recommend you to watch another anime you want to see first.

I started watching not really knowing what to expect except that a guy turns into a girl and fights other girls.
And it started off really nice and I enjoyed.
Later on it became clear that it wanted to be a harem story. I normally don't mind those stories, but the main male lead was the typical male harem lead with no clue about what the woman truly felt and in his case not even one working brain cell. The only thing that kept me watching was the character Shizuku Sangouthe and the mysteries that surrounded the Kämpfer. The other two girls vying for his attention arenicely thought out as well, but Shizuku Sangouthe is the one standing out from the entire show.\n\n
I had some hope and those hopes got a positive feedback the first two episodes. It was around episode 6 that the harem story came into full view. \n
But they ruined everything with the last few episodes.\n\n
I have to say I am disappointing on how this anime turned out.\n
It started of strong became mediocre and turned bad. It's a shame because it could have been something better, even something good.

So, I had high hopes for this anime after reading a lot of the manga. However, most of the more mature themes in the story, such as death and politics, got ripped out and all that was left was ecchi. In the manga, Natsuru struggles with the moral implications of the Kampfer battles, but we see very little of that in the anime. In fact, it's been a while, but I seem to recall nobody was ever really killed in the anime, which removes all gravity from the battles since you know everyone's always gonna be ok. Also, in the manga, Shizuku was always probingaround trying to get more clues on who was overseeing the Kampfer battles, setting up clever ruses to lure them out and expose themselves, but that didn't happen. If I recall correctly, she just makes a snap judgement in the last episode with very little evidence. Additionally, a lot of the characters and situations from the second half of the manga weren't included, so really, this pretty much ended up being a big fan-service blowout until the very end where they had to rush the conclusion of the story. It was all over too quickly and there was very little character development. It's sad to see the potential of the original story go to waste, but this will probably be the only anime adaptation we'll ever get. Oh well. It's still worth watching to see some of the more notable ecchi scenes from the manga animated though, if you're so inclined. Just don't expect anything much deeper than that.
